unicode.value: In the waves
María Dolores Ávila Martín, Céline Marie C. Camerlynck, José María de la Torre López, Antonio Romero Algarín, Carlos Ríos Ruiz, Lucía Fernández Paredes, María Rosario Reyes Márquez

Este recurso, dirigido al alumnado de 3º y 4º de la ESO, tiene como objetivo fundamental la creación de un programa de radio en el que se comenten noticias y se expresen opiniones con la cohesión y la coherencia propia del formato radiofónico. Para conseguirlo, se requiere que el alumnado redacte acerca de hechos objetivos, discrimine las noticias fiables de las que no lo son, distinga la expresión de una noticia de la expresión de un punto de vista y conozca la manera en la que se relacionan y ordenan las distintas secciones de un programa de radio.
Una vez el programa esté terminado, supondrá un acercamiento al modo en el que los medios de comunicación se relacionan con su audiencia a la par que resultará en un registro sonoro del alumnado que participó en él.

In the waves
Text and Tasks
1. Viral

Dictionary

Matter

Definition:

An idea about which something is either thought, written or said.

Una idea acerca de la que se piensa, se escribe os se dice algo.

Example:

The human condition is the matter philosophy deals with.

La condición humana es la cuestión de la que trata la filosofía.

Spanish word:

Cuestión

Audio:

Networking

Definition:

The sharing of data and information among people.

El acto de compartir datos e información entre personas.

Example:

Nowadays, networking makes information flow as ever before.

Hoy en día, la interconexión hace que la información fluya como nunca antes.

Spanish word:

Interconexión

Audio:

Subject

Definition:

What something is about.

De lo que trata algo.

Example:

Your proposal is interesting, but it has little to do with the subject of this discussion.

Tu propuesta es interesante, pero tiene poco que ver con el tema que estamos discutiendo.

Spanish word:

Tema

Audio:
Text and Tasks
1. What’s up?

Nowadays, you are a click away from any information around: you can post pictures or share memes online, read and share any type of news you hear or read and, give your opinion about any subject matter on your social media.  But, is everything you read online true? Do you know how to distinguish information from opinion?

Definition:

To incorporate something to something else.

Incorporar algo a otra cosa.

Example:

If the rice is too dry you may add some stock.

Si el arroz está demasiado seco puedes añadir algo de caldo.

Definition:

Informal talk, usually between people who know each other.

Conversación informal, normalmente entre gente que ya se conoce.

Example:

I always feel better after chatting with my sister.

Siempre me encuentro mejor después de charlar con mi hermana.

Definition:

The sharing of data and information among people.

El acto de compartir datos e información entre personas.

Example:

Nowadays, networking makes information flow as ever before.

Hoy en día, la interconexión hace que la información fluya como nunca antes.
Text and Tasks
2. News or opinion?
Option A. Piece of news or opinion?

Which of these statements is a piece of the news and which expresses an opinion? Choose the correct option.

Definition:

A declaration or observation about something.

Una declaración u observación sobre algo.

Example:

The prime minister's statement suprised everybody.

La declaración de la primera ministra sorprendió a todo el mundo.

4. Mass media
A. Mass media vocabulary
UDL Content

Radio, TV, newspapers. All of them belong to mass media. Do you know the meaning of the following words?

Television

Generalist Television: A TV channel that offers a wide variety of programs, including news, entertainment, sports, and documentaries, aiming to appeal to a broad audience. Example: RTVE.

Private Television: A TV channels or networks that are owned by private companies or individuals, rather than the government. These channels often generate revenue through advertisements and subscriptions. Examples: Antena 3, Telecinco

Specialized Television: A TV channel that focuses on specific types of content, such as sports, movies, or cooking shows, targeting a particular interest group. Example: HISTORIA

Platform Television: A service or app (like Netflix or YouTube) that allows users to access TV shows and movies on demand, usually via the internet, instead of traditional broadcast TV. Example: Atresmedia, Mediaset
 

Radio

Radio Station: A broadcast service that transmits radio programs, including music, news, and talk shows, through the airwaves for listeners to tune into via radios or online. Example: La Ser, Ondacero.

Radio Podcast: A digital audio program available on demand, often in the form of a series, which listeners can download or stream. It’s like a radio show but available whenever you want.

Newspaper

Tabloid: A type of newspaper or magazine that focuses on sensational stories, gossip, and celebrity news, often with bold headlines and pictures.

Broadsheet: A type of newspaper that focuses on serious news, politics, and in-depth analysis, typically with more text and less sensationalism compared to tabloids.

Text and Tasks
5. Journalistic texts
1. What you need to know

Video

Click here to read the subtitles

Notes

  • News are facts. Facts are the same for everybody.  (Los hechos son iguales para todo el mundo)
  • Opinions are not facts. Opinions are not the same for everybody. (Las opiniones no son las mismas para todo el mundo)

You will find both news and opinions in the media. (Ambas aparecen en los medios de comunicación)

HOW TO EXPRESS OPINION:

  • I think / believe that...
  • In my opinion,...
  • As I see it,...
  • From my point of view,...
  • I agree with...
  • I disagree with...

Make your opinions stronger with adverbs: definitely, firmly, truly, strongly or really. (Haz que tu opinión suene más fuerte con adverbios):

  • I firmly believe that the future will be better than the past.
  • They really dislike what the president said.
  • I strongly disagree with you.

When an opinion is given, it’s always a good idea to explain it. Use because and since. (Cuando expreses tu opinión es bueno explicar el porqué):

  • I strongly disagree with banning mobile phones at school because they are a great learning tool.
  • I think it’s a good idea to ban mobiles at school since they are very distracting.

Lectura facilitada

Read

 News are facts.
Facts are the same for everybody.

Las noticias son hechos.

Los hechos son los mismos para todos.

 Different people have different opinions.
In order to express opinions:

Las opiniones cambian según la persona.

Para opinar:

 You use the verbs “believe”, “like” or “”think”.
You use these verbs in the affirmative.
You use these verbs in the negative.

- Usas los verbos “creer”, “gustar” o “pensar” para opinar.

- Usas estos verbos en afirmativo.

- Usas estos verbos en negativo.

  You use expressions such as:
- As I see it.
- From my point of view.
- In my opinion.
- I agree.
- I disagree.

 - Usas expresiones como:

  • Tal y como yo lo veo.
  • Desde mi punto de vista.
  • En mi opinión.
  • Estoy de acuerdo.
  • No estoy de acuerdo.

 You use adverbs such as:
- Definitely.
- Firmly.
- Truly.
- Strongly.
- Really.

 -Usas adverbios como:

  • Definitivamente.
  • Firmemente.
  • Verdaderamente.
  • Fuertemente.
  • Realmente.

 You express your opinion.

 Explicas tu opinión.

 There are different roles in the media:
- Hosts and reporters tell the news.
- Panellists give their opinions

Hay distintos roles en los medios:

  • Los presentadores y reporteros cuentas noticias.
  • Los tertulianos dan su opinión.
4.4. An opinion article
Text and Tasks
5.1. News article
Model text
UDL Content

NEW SKATE PARK OPENS IN SEVILLE

By Laura Gómez

Seville, March 2, 2025

A young boy skating in the new park.

The mayor of Seville opened a new skate park in the city yesterday. With this action, he keeps his promise to young citizens, who claimed for a park since 2019.

The skate park is in María Luisa Park and was officially opened yesterday. Many teenagers attended the event and tried the facilities. The park has ramps, rails, and a special area for beginners. The city built the park to offer a safe place for skateboarding.  Carlos, a 14-year-old skater, said, "Now we have a place to practice without problems." The local government announced that competitions and workshops for beginners will be organized soon.

News article structure

News articles have the following parts:

  • Headline: The title of the news story. It tells you what the article is about in a few words.
  • Author, time and date.
  • Image and caption: photograph and a description of what you can see in the image.
  • Lead: The first part of the article. It gives you the most important information and answers the basic questions 5W (who, what, when, where, why). Sometimes you can add "how".
  • Body: The rest of the article. It explains the details, background, and gives more information about the story.

Useful language

Introducing the story:

"A new event took place in..."
"Thousands of people attended..."
"The event was held to..."


Explaining details:

"The main reason for the event was..."
"The project aims to..."
"This was the first time that..."

Giving quotes:

"According to..."
"As [name], a [job/role], said..."
"[Name] explained that..."


Describing the scene:

"The streets were filled with..."
"The crowd cheered as..."
"The weather was perfect for..."


Concluding the article:

"In conclusion, this event has shown that..."
"Looking ahead, people are excited about..."
"The local community is now hoping that..."

General tips

  • Be clear and concise: Keep sentences short and easy to understand.
  • Use facts, not opinions: A news article should focus on facts, not personal opinions.
  • Use quotes to make it real: Include quotes from people involved to make the article more engaging.
  • Stay objective: Don’t show personal feelings, focus on the facts and the information that readers need to know.

5.2. A report
Model text
UDL Content

EXCITEMENT AT THE SEVILLE MARATHON

Diego Máquez. Seville, 14 March 2025

Runners reaching the finish line.

Seville, March 2, 2025 – Thousands of runners filled the streets yesterday for the annual Seville Marathon, enjoying perfect weather and cheering crowds.

The race began at 8 a.m. near Plaza de España. Among the participants was 17-year-old Marta López, running her first marathon. “I trained for months, and I’m excited,” she said.

Runners passed iconic landmarks like the Cathedral and the Guadalquivir River. Many struggled near the 35-kilometer mark, but the crowd’s energy kept them going. David Fernández, 22, shared, “I was exhausted, but the support helped me finish.”

Kenyan runner Joseph Kiplagat won in 2 hours and 10 minutes. Local athlete Antonio Muñoz, finishing in 2 hours and 35 minutes, said, “Running in my city is a dream.”

The event ended with hugs, photos, and celebrations, proving once again that the Seville Marathon is more than just a race—it’s a test of endurance and community spirit.

A report structure

A report presents a more detailed account of an event that is of interest to readers. It can offer a broader view of a news story, although reports can also be written about topics that are not current. Some tips to write a report:

A report has the following parts:

  • Headline – It is the title of the news report. It is short and catches the reader’s attention.

    Example: "Thousands Run in Seville Marathon"

  • Author, date and time.

  • Lead – It is the first sentence or paragraph. It gives the most important information: Who? What? When? Where?

    Example: "Seville, March 2, 2025 – Thousands of runners filled the streets yesterday for the annual Seville Marathon."

  • Image and caption (description of the image)

  • Body – It gives more details about the event. It answers Why? How? and includes quotes, facts, and descriptions.

    Example: "The race began at 8 a.m. near Plaza de España. Among the participants was 17-year-old Marta López, running her first marathon."

  • Closing – It is the last part. It gives a final thought or a conclusion.

    Example: "The event ended with hugs, photos, and celebrations, proving once again that the Seville Marathon is more than just a race—it’s a test of endurance and community spirit."

Useful language

1. Headline (Title)
"Big Crowd at [Event]"
"[Person] Wins [Competition]"
"[Event] Happened in [Place]"


2. Lead (Introduction: Who? What? When? Where?)
"[Event] took place in [Place] on [Date]."
"[Number] people joined [Event] yesterday."
"[Person] said, 'I am happy to be here!'"

3. Body (Details: Why? How? Quotes?)
"Many people enjoyed the event because..."
"[Person] explained, 'It was very exciting.'"
"The crowd cheered as [Person] finished the race."

4. Closing (Final Thought, Impact)
"Everyone had a great time at [Event]."
"[Event] was a big success for the city."
"People are already looking forward to next year."

General tips

  • Use a clear and catchy headline.
  • Dive deeper into the events. 
  • Start with the most important information (Lead). Answer Who? What? When? Where? in the first sentence. Keep it short and clear.
  • Give more details in the body. Answer Why? How? and include facts.
  • Write in a neutral and objective tone. A news report gives facts, not opinions.
  • Use short paragraphs and simple sentences.
  • End with a strong conclusion. Summarize the event. Mention its importance or future impact.
  • Check grammar and spelling.

The event ended with hugs, photos, and celebrations, proving once again that the Seville Marathon is more than just a race—it’s a test of endurance and community spirit.

 Body
EXCITEMENT AT THE SEVILLE MARATHON
By Diego Máquez. Seville, 14 March 2025
Seville, March 14, 2025
Runners reaching the finish line.
Seville, March 2, 2025 – Thousands of runners filled the streets yesterday for the annual Seville Marathon, enjoying perfect weather and cheering crowds.

The race began at 8 a.m. near Plaza de España. Among the participants was 17-year-old Marta López, running her first marathon. “I trained for months, and I’m excited,” she said.

Runners passed iconic landmarks like the Cathedral and the Guadalquivir River. Many struggled near the 35-kilometer mark, but the crowd’s energy kept them going. David Fernández, 22, shared, “I was exhausted, but the support helped me finish.”

Kenyan runner Joseph Kiplagat won in 2 hours and 10 minutes. Local athlete Antonio Muñoz, finishing in 2 hours and 35 minutes, said, “Running in my city is a dream.”

The event ended with hugs, photos, and celebrations, proving once again that the Seville Marathon is more than just a race—it’s a test of endurance and community spirit.

5.3. An interview
Sample text
UDL Content

OLIVIA RODRIGO: "MUSIC IS A WAY TO EXPRESS EMOTIONS"

Marta Marín. Seville, 25th March 2025.

Olivia Rodrigo playing the guitar for he photo shoot.


Many teenagers around the world love Olivia Rodrigo’s music. She became famous with her song Drivers License and now she is one of the most popular young singers. In this interview, she talks about her career, her inspiration, and her advice for young artists.

Interviewer: Hello, Olivia! Thank you for talking with us today.

Olivia Rodrigo: Hi! I’m happy to be here.

Interviewer: Many teenagers love your music. How did you start your career?

Olivia Rodrigo: I started singing when I was a child. I also acted in TV shows. Then, I wrote my first song and became a singer.

Interviewer: Your songs are very emotional. Where do you get your inspiration?

Olivia Rodrigo: I write about my life and my feelings. I think music is a way to express emotions.

Interviewer: What is your favorite song from your albums?

Olivia Rodrigo: It’s hard to choose! But I really love Drivers License because it changed my life.

Interviewer: What do you do when you are not working?

Olivia Rodrigo: I like reading, watching movies, and spending time with my friends.

Interviewer: What advice do you have for young people who want to be singers?

Olivia Rodrigo: Work hard and believe in yourself. Write your own songs and practice a lot!

Interviewer: Thank you, Olivia! Good luck with your music!

Olivia Rodrigo: Thank you so much!

Olivia Rodrigo continues to inspire young people with her music and her message. During our conversation, she smiled when talking about her fans and showed how much she appreciates them. With her talent and passion, she has become one of the most successful artists of her generation. Fans can’t wait to hear more from her in the future!

Structure

An interview is a journalistic genre in which a dialogue with a public figure is presented. It is a planned conversation, meaning the interviewer prepares questions in advance to learn about the interviewee’s opinions, thoughts, knowledge, and experiences.


An interview usually has three main parts:

Headline:

  • It should be short and interesting.
  • It can include a key phrase from the interviewee to attract attention.

Introduction:

  • Provides background information about the interviewee.
  • Explains why the person is important or relevant.
  • Mentions the main topic of the interview.

Dialogue (Questions and Answers):

  • The interviewer asks questions, and the interviewee responds.
  • The questions should be clear and related to the topic.
  • The conversation should be natural and informative.

Conclusion (Optional)

  • A short closing statement or a final message from the interviewee.
  • It can include a thank-you note from the interviewer.

Dr. Jane Smith: "Science is for everyone, especially young minds" Headline
Laura Ramz. Córdoba, 17 March 2025
 Author and date
Picture
Jane Smith working in her laboratory. Caption
Dr. Jane Smith is a well-known scientist and educator who has dedicated her career to inspiring young people to explore science. She works on projects that help teenagers understand space, technology, and the environment. In this interview, she shares her passion for science, her work with students, and her advice for young future scientists. Introduction

Interviewer: Hello, Dr. Smith! Thank you for joining us today.

Dr. Jane Smith: Hello! I’m happy to be here and talk about science with you.

Interviewer: Many teenagers are curious about science. How did you become a scientist?

Dr. Jane Smith: I have always loved asking questions about the world. When I was a child, I enjoyed looking at the stars and reading about space. Later, I studied physics and became an astrophysicist.

Interviewer: That sounds amazing! You also work with young students. Why is that important to you?

Dr. Jane Smith: Teenagers have great ideas and creativity. I believe the next big scientific discoveries will come from young minds. That’s why I love working with students and encouraging them to explore science.

Interviewer: What is the most exciting project you have worked on?

Dr. Jane Smith: One of my favorite projects was helping high school students build a small satellite. We launched it into space, and they could see their own work orbiting Earth!

Interviewer: Wow! That must have been incredible. What advice do you have for teenagers who love science?

Dr. Jane Smith: Be curious and never stop asking questions. Science is not about knowing everything—it’s about discovering new things. Also, don’t be afraid to make mistakes. Every mistake is a step toward learning.

Interviewer: Before we finish, do you have a message for young people who want to be scientists?

Dr. Jane Smith: Yes! Science is for everyone, no matter who you are. If you are passionate about it, follow your dreams and find ways to learn more. The world needs young scientists like you!

Interviewer: Thank you, Dr. Smith! It was inspiring to talk to you.

Dr. Jane Smith: Thank you! Keep exploring and discovering!

 Dialogue
Dr. Jane Smith is a true inspiration for young scientists. During our conversation, her eyes lit up when talking about students’ creativity and future discoveries. With her work, she continues to show that science is exciting and open to everyone. Who knows? Maybe the next great scientist is reading this interview right now! Conclusion

B. Comprehension activity 1
University of Auckland

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible

6. Audio story

Dictionary

Closing

Definition:

Final idea a text arrives at.

Idea final a la que llega un texto.

Example:

The closing of the text shows how intelligent the author is.

La conlusión del texto demuestra lo inteligente que la autora es.

Spanish word:

Conclusión

Audio:

Concise

Definition:

Expressed in a short and exact way.

Expresado de manera breve y exacta.

Example:

My aunt wrote a concise but loving birthday card.

Mi tía escribió una concisa pero cariñosa tarjeta de cumpleaños.

Spanish word:

Concisa

Audio:

Factual

Definition:

Something that is real and can be tested as true.

Algo que es real y puede ser demostrado como cierto.

Example:

The figures in that article are not factual.

Las cifras de ese artículo no están fundamentadas.

Spanish word:

Fundamentada

Audio:

Greeting

Definition:

The act of saluting somebody.

El acto de saludar a alguien.

Example:

The dog's greeting to his owner woke up the whole building.

El saludo del perro a su dueño despertó a todo el edificio.

Spanish word:

Saludo

Audio:

Host

Definition:

Person in charge of conducting a program.

Persona encargada de conducir un programa.

Example:

The host read the news about the accident.

El presentador leyó la noticia del accidente.

Spanish word:

Presentador

Audio:

Lead

Definition:

Part of a text in which its ideas and purposes are introduced.

Parte de un texto en la que se presentan sus ideas y propósitos.

Example:

A good lead makes understanding a text easier.

Una buena introducción hace que el texto se entienda mejor.

Spanish word:

Introducción

Audio:

Reliable

Definition:

Somebody or something that can be relied on.

Alguien o algo del que nos podemos fiar.

Example:

Reliable journalists are essential in democracy.

Los periodistas fiables son esenciales para la democracia.

Spanish word:

Fiable

Audio:

Reporter

Definition:

A person who reports the news.

Persona que informa de las noticias.

Example:

Reporters usually inform from where events took place.

Los reporteros suelen informar desde donde sucedieron los hechos.

Spanish word:

Reportero

Audio:

Summary

Definition:

A brief compilation of the most important ideas of a text.

Breve recopilación de las ideas más importantes de un texto.

Example:

The summary on the back cover gives you an idea of what a book is about.

El resumen de la contraportada te da una idea del tema de libro.

Spanish word:

Resumen

Audio:

Read

 A news bulletin lasts three minutes.
They tell about eight stories in one bulletin.

Cuentan unas 8 historias en el noticiero.

 You select interesting stories.

 Seleccionas historias interesantes.

 You check the story is real.

 Verificas que la historia es real.

 You identify fake news:
- Watch the date of the piece of news.
- The headline coincides with the content.
- The body of the piece of news:
     - It uses appropriate language.
     - The references are good.
     - Spelling and grammar are correct.
     - The website or newspaper are reliable.

Identificas noticias falsas:

- Fíjate en la fecha de la noticia.

-El titular coincide con el contenido.

-El cuerpo de la noticia:

  • Usa un lenguaje adecuado.
  • Las referencias son buenas.
  • La ortografía y gramática es correcta.
  • El sitio web o periódico es creíble.

 You compare the piece of news in different languages.
- You create a piece of news:
     - Decide on the main story.
     - Classify the stories according to their topic.
     - Choose a funny story to end.

Comparas la noticia en otros idiomas.

Creas una noticia así:

- Decides la historia principal.

- Clasificas las historias según su temática.

- Acabas con una noticia divertida.

 You write the audio script story.

Escribes un guión de una noticia de radio.

 A radio news story is a short report.
A radio news bulletin lasts between 20 and 60 seconds.
The news informs.
The news is divided in:

Una noticia de radio es un informe corto.

Una noticia de radio dura entre 20 y 60 segundos.

La noticia informa.

La noticia se divide en:

 Welcome:
- Greeting and presentation.
- The radio host says the day.

Bienvenida:

  • Saludo y presentación.
  • El presentador dice el día que es.

 Lead:
- The lead presents the stories.
- The lead lasts 5 seconds.
- The radio host reads the lead.

Introducción:

  • La introducción presenta las historias.
  • La introducción dura 5 segundos.
  • El locutor lee la introducción.

 The main body:
- Answers the questions:
     Who, where, when, what, and why.
- The reporter reads the body.

Cuerpo principal:

  • Responde a las preguntas:
  • Quién, dónde, cuándo, qué, por qué.

El reportero lee el cuerpo principal.

 Summary:
- You go over the story shortly.
- The reporter reads the summary.

- Resumen:

  • Repasas los hechos contados.
  • El reportero lee el resumen.

 Closing: end of the programme.

 Cierre: despedida del programa.

1. Las funciones principales son:

Locutores de radio, reporteros,  tertulianos y técnicos de sonido.

Veamos cada uno.

 Radio hosts start and guide the programme. They must:
- Welcome and say goodbye.
- Introduce different sections.
- Give the floor to guests.
- Control speaking time.
Hosts use special sentences on the radio.
You can read sentences in the presentation.

Los locutores inician y guían el programa.

Ellos deben:

  • Dar la bienvenida y despedida.
  • Introducir diferentes secciones.
  • Dar la palabra a diferentes invitados.
  • Controlar el tiempo de palabra.

Los locutores  usan frases especiales en la radio. 

Tú puedes leer las frases en la presentación.

 Reporters tell the news. They must:
- Investigate and fact check the news.
- Write the news.
- Say the news headlines.
- Say the news details.

Los reporteros cuentan las noticias.

Ellos deben:

  • Investigar y verificar las noticias.
  • Escribir la noticia.
  • Decir los titulares de la noticia.
  • Decir detalles de la noticia.

 Panellits must:
- Greet the host.
- Give their opinion.
- Respect others.

Los tertulianos deben:

  • Saludar al locutor.
  • Dar sus opiniones.
  • Respetar a los demás.

1. Welcome to Radio Andalusia

In teams, design the outline of a radio show. It must feature both news and opinions. Don’t forget to cast each role (presenters, reporters and panellists giving their opinion).

Remember to:

  • Do some research and choose a topic. 
  • Distribute the roles:
    • Hosts read the opening, introduce the reporter and the panellist and read the closing.
    • News reporters select sources and check the news. Before they write the audio script, they compare the stories in different languages and rank them.
    • Panellists express their opinions.
    • Sound technicians find bumpers and record and edit tracks.
  • Write the outline.

Motus dice ... How much do your classmates know?

When we work in a group, we also learn as a team. 

There are classmates who remember a lot of things, others who speak very well, others who are very skilled with their hands or feet, others who are great at drawing. 

We all have superpowers, but when we combine them, we learn together and we can solve any challenge. 

That's why it's important that your team follows these tips:

- Everything one person knows is shared with others. 

- We work together so that the team work. 

- We value each person's superpowers. 

- We respect what each person shares with the team.

Text and Tasks
3. To sum up

To conclude, let's remember the strategy or "trick" that you have learned during this challenge. 

We taught you this strategy or "trick" and you worked on it in the section “Fact-checkers”. Go back to that section and review for a moment what it consisted of and how it helped you achieve the challenge we proposed. Now open the Learning Diary and complete the last page. 

In this section, you will keep valuable information about the strategy, in which activities you have applied it, whether it has been useful and what has been the most difficult for you. 

Keep up the good work, you're doing great! For your effort, you have earned your first badge here, which you will be credited with as Mega Strategist. Congratulations! 

Remember: 

- Ask your teacher whether you will fill it in on paper or on the computer. 

- If you fill it in on your pc, don't forget to save it on your computer when you finish it!

¿Necesitas más ayuda?

Para concluir, vamos a recordar la estrategia o el “truco” que has aprendido durante este reto. 

Esta estrategia o “truco” te lo enseñamos y lo trabajaste en el apartado “ Fact-checkers”.  Vuelve a dicho apartado y repasa un momento en qué consistía y cómo te sirvió para llegar a conseguir el reto que te proponíamos. Abre, ahora, el Diario de Aprendizaje y completa su última página. 

En este apartado guardarás información valiosa sobre la estrategia, en qué actividades las has aplicado, si ha sido útil y qué te ha resultado más difícil.

¡Sigue trabajando así! ¡Lo estás haciendo genial! Por tu esfuerzo has conseguido aquí la primera insignia que te acreditará como Mega-Estratega. ¡Enhorabuena! 

Recuerda: 

• Pregunta a tu profesor o profesora si la rellenarás en papel o en el ordenador. 

• Si la rellenas en el ordenador, ¡no te olvides de guardarla en tu ordenador cuando la termines!

 ExcellentGoodNeeds improvementLow performance
1. You can select reliable news, source it and identify fake news.The selected piece of news has been sourced and checked appropriately to exclude fake news. (10)The selected piece of news has been sourced and checked appropriately, however, not every detail has been taken into account to exclude fake news. (7,5)The selected piece of news has been sourced and checked inappropriately to exclude fake news. (5)The selected piece of news has not been sourced and checked appropriately to exclude fake news. (2,5)
2. You can compare a selected story in different languages.One or more selected stories have been found and compared in different languages. (10)One or more selected stories have been found in different languages but the comparison was only partially done. (7,5)One or more stories have been found in different languages but no comparison was done. (5)No one story was found in another language. (2,5)
3. You can write the different parts of a news story in a clear, coherent and correct way.Your audio radio script includes its different parts and features and is clear, coherent and correct. (10)Your audio radio script includes its different parts and features but is not always clear, coherent and correct. (7,5)Your audio radio script includes its different parts and features but is often unclear, incoherent and incorrect. (5)Your audio radio script includes its different parts and but it does not include the features of an audio script. (2,5)
4. You can tell a piece of news from an opinion.You always spot the verbs and expressions that let you know when an opinion is expressed. (10)You sometimes spot the verbs and expressions that let you know when an opinion is expressed. (7,5)You seldom spot the verbs and expressions that let you know when an opinion is expressed. (5)You never spot the verbs and expressions that let you know when an opinion is expressed. (2,5)
5. You can express opinions about the news.You always make use of the verbs and expressions that let opinions be expressed. (10)You sometimes make use of the verbs and expressions that let opinions be expressed. (7,5)You seldom make use of the verbs and expressions that let opinions be expressed. (5)You never make use of the verbs and expressions that let opinions be expressed. (2,5)
6. You can create a radio outline.The outline includes timing, different roles and contents for a radio programme in a very cohesive way. (10)The outline includes timing, different roles and contents for a radio programme in a cohesive way most of the time. (7,5)The outline includes only some sections of a radio programme or it is sometimes not cohesive enough. (5)The outline does not include the sections of a radio programme or it is not cohesive. (2,5)
7. You can record and edit a radio programme.Your records are very clear and they are edited using digital resources and the outline with accuracy. (10)Your records are clear most of the time and they are edited using digital resources and the outline. (7,5)Your records are sometimes clear, and they are edited using digital resources and the outline with some inconsistencies. (5)Your records are not very clear, and its edition using digital resources does not follow the outline. (2,5)

María Dolores Ávila Martín, Céline Marie C. Camerlynck, José María de la Torre López, Antonio Romero Algarín, Carlos Ríos Ruiz, Lucía Fernández Paredes, María Rosario Reyes Márquez

Este recurso, dirigido al alumnado de 3º y 4º de la ESO, tiene como objetivo fundamental la creación de un programa de radio en el que se comenten noticias y se expresen opiniones con la cohesión y la coherencia propia del formato radiofónico. Para conseguirlo, se requiere que el alumnado redacte acerca de hechos objetivos, discrimine las noticias fiables de las que no lo son, distinga la expresión de una noticia de la expresión de un punto de vista y conozca la manera en la que se relacionan y ordenan las distintas secciones de un programa de radio.
Una vez el programa esté terminado, supondrá un acercamiento al modo en el que los medios de comunicación se relacionan con su audiencia a la par que resultará en un registro sonoro del alumnado que participó en él.

Una vez el programa est\xc3\xa9 terminado, supondr\xc3\xa1 un acercamiento al modo en el que los medios de comunicaci\xc3\xb3n se relacionan con su audiencia a la par que resultar\xc3\xa1 en un registro sonoro del alumnado que particip\xc3\xb3 en \xc3\xa9l.

Camerlynck, Jos\xc3\xa9 Mar\xc3\xada de la Torre L\xc3\xb3pez, Antonio Romero Algar\xc3\xadn, Carlos R\xc3\xados Ruiz, Luc\xc3\xada Fern\xc3\xa1ndez Paredes, Mar\xc3\xada Rosario Reyes M\xc3\xa1rquez EMAIL;TYPE=INTERNET: ORG: END:VCARD

Este REA tiene dos objetivos: concienciar al alumnado de los factores que influyen en la interacci\xc3\xb3n y plantear c\xc3\xb3mo el buen uso de estos factores afecta a la calidad de las relaciones interpersonales. Para ello, abordamos los siguientes temas: estructura de preguntas, frases cortas, comunicaci\xc3\xb3n no verbal y estilos de comunicaci\xc3\xb3n.\n\nEl alumnado elaborar\xc3\xa1 un informe sobre su perfil como interlocutor que incluir\xc3\xa1 el feedback de sus iguales. Este se consigue mediante la participaci\xc3\xb3n en una actividad de Speed Dating con las personas de la clase. Este REA prepara al alumnado para que pueda participar con \xc3\xa9xito en esta actividad.

Los objetivos que se fija este REA son dos: poder hablar y solicitar informaci\xc3\xb3n sobre nuestras actividades cotidianas, nuestras preferencias y aficiones, y ser capaces de compartir en medios digitales y redes sociales esta informaci\xc3\xb3n de una forma segura cuando compartimos v\xc3\xaddeos. Para esto, se aprender\xc3\xa1n conceptos audiovisuales b\xc3\xa1sicos, as\xc3\xad como consejos de seguridad en la red, de modo que se pueda controlar lo que se comparte y con qui\xc3\xa9n se comparte. \nPara culminar con \xc3\xa9xito este REA, el alumnado tendr\xc3\xa1 que elaborar su propia v\xc3\xaddeo-presentaci\xc3\xb3n para compartir en redes sociales o canales del centro, teniendo en cuenta un dec\xc3\xa1logo de seguridad a la hora de compartir contenidos personales en internet o redes sociales. A trav\xc3\xa9s de las distintas p\xc3\xa1ginas y actividades, los alumnos tendr\xc3\xa1n que reflexionar sobre su d\xc3\xada a d\xc3\xada, seleccionar la informaci\xc3\xb3n que quieren compartir y realizar pr\xc3\xa1cticas de v\xc3\xaddeo grabaci\xc3\xb3n hasta llegar a la tarea final.

El arte urbano se encuentra en muchos rincones de casi todas las ciudades, y en este REA se pretende que los j\xc3\xb3venes miren a su alrededor con ojos cr\xc3\xadticos, aprendiendo a distinguir la creaci\xc3\xb3n art\xc3\xadstica en las calles y algunos de los mensajes que transmiten. En este recurso conocer\xc3\xa1n distintas modalidades de arte urbano, como expresi\xc3\xb3n art\xc3\xadstica y como reivindicaci\xc3\xb3n. Adem\xc3\xa1s, aprender\xc3\xa1n c\xc3\xb3mo crear un folleto para convocar un concurso de arte urbano en su centro educativo, integrando toda la informaci\xc3\xb3n necesaria. El uso de los verbos modales permitir\xc3\xa1 a los estudiantes dar e interpretar instrucciones correctamente.

El REA Fans, fandoms and fanatics tiene como objetivo fundamental la creaci\xc3\xb3n de un club social de fans de libros, pel\xc3\xadculas, videojuegos o c\xc3\xb3mics. Este formato requiere que el alumnado tome decisiones sobre el funcionamiento del mismo y elija su tema principal, busque a sus miembros y el lugar de celebraci\xc3\xb3n, etc.\nUna vez puestas las bases fundamentales del club, lo utilizar\xc3\xa1 para compartir opiniones y creaciones de sus miembros, por lo que escribir rese\xc3\xb1as ser\xc3\xa1 clave para su desarrollo.

Este recurso, dirigido al alumnado de 3\xc2\xba y 4\xc2\xba de la ESO, tiene como objetivo fundamental la creaci\xc3\xb3n de un programa de radio en el que se comenten noticias y se expresen opiniones con la cohesi\xc3\xb3n y la coherencia propia del formato radiof\xc3\xb3nico. Para conseguirlo, se requiere que el alumnado redacte acerca de hechos objetivos, discrimine las noticias fiables de las que no lo son, distinga la expresi\xc3\xb3n de una noticia de la expresi\xc3\xb3n de un punto de vista y conozca la manera en la que se relacionan y ordenan las distintas secciones de un programa de radio. 

Una vez el programa est\xc3\xa9 terminado, supondr\xc3\xa1 un acercamiento al modo en el que los medios de comunicaci\xc3\xb3n se relacionan con su audiencia a la par que resultar\xc3\xa1 en un registro sonoro del alumnado que particip\xc3\xb3 en \xc3\xa9l.
